entry.title: Combined summary - Roadmap/schedules
entry.summary: The Bitcoin Core developers, including Gavin Andresen and Matt Corallo, are actively working towards improving the cryptocurrency's network health, wallet security, bug fixing, and thorough testing. In an email exchange from August 2011, Gavin Andresen outlined his priorities for Bitcoin development, which included network health and wallet security, as well as proposing the creation of a dedicated "core bitcoin quality assurance team." Additionally, he suggested research-y features like impolite peer detection/reaction and code for mining pool participants.Andresen also suggested creating a companion website and project that can centralize contributions from various monitors and tests to ensure the network's health. He emphasized the importance of wallet security and called for volunteers to prioritize/assign bugs and ensure they get closed when they're fixed. As for testing, Andresen suggested more unit tests and automated testing while welcoming help in finding money and/or people for a dedicated "core bitcoin quality assurance team."In another email exchange from the same time period, Matt Corallo expressed his desire to prioritize wallet security and requested the encryption to be shipped soon along with the Multisign patch. However, he noted that there is a lack of documentation on how to prepare bitcoind installations for encryption. Regarding testing, Matt mentioned that he does not have enough time to test every pull request personally. He plans to write something up on it.The group also discussed upgrades for a certain system and raised concerns about new code causing critical section deadlocks. They suggested implementing locks that track ordering relative to other locks and running ThreadSanitizer to identify thread safety issues.Overall, the Bitcoin Core developers are seeking help in finding people or money to create a dedicated "core bitcoin quality assurance team," and have proposed several features they would like to see in future releases. Andresen listed five priorities including network health, detecting potential deadlocks early, wallet security, bug fixing, and thorough testing. The developers are actively working towards improving the cryptocurrency's infrastructure and addressing any issues that arise.
